quoteFirst: In cold, winter weather at Paris, the one journey is certainly preferable, and at the end of it people arrive in what is by contrast a genial summer. So proceeding, passengers have, besides other shorter stoppages, an interval of half an hour at Dijon, at 5.45 P.M., to dine; 25 minutes at Lyons, at
quoteLast: ; and the following morning, at 6.30 A.M., 1 hour 25 minutes at Marseilles to wash and breakfast.
title:
Wintering in the Riviera
With Notes of Travel in Italy and France, and Practical Hints to Travellers
author: Miller, William James, 1850-

quoteFirst: On the 1st, the moon sets at 12:38 a. m.; on the 15th, rises at 11:45 p. m.; and on the 29th, sets at 11:42 p. m. Is farthest from the earth on the 16th, at
quoteLast: ; nearest to earth on 21st, at 10:30 p. m. Least meridian altitude on 9th, 29° 41′; greatest altitude on the 22nd, amounting to 67° 18⅓′.
title: The Chautauquan, Vol. 04, June 1884, No. 9
author: Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle; Chautauqua Institution; Flood, Theodore L., 1842- [Editor]

quoteFirst: Will be morning star, although visible nearly the entire night, and will increase in diameter from 18.8″ to 19.4″. Will have a retrograde motion of 2° 8′ 38″, and on the 5th, at
quoteLast: , will be 3° 23′ north of the moon. On the 1st, will rise at 7:25 p. m., and on the next morning set at 10:03 a. m.; on the 16th, will rise at 6:22 p. m.
title: The Chautauquan, Vol. 05, November 1884, No. 2
author: Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle; Chautauqua Institution; Flood, Theodore L., 1842- [Editor]
